content.title: Climate Requirements for Crested Geckos
content.content: Crested geckos are cool-temperature species from the cloud forests of New Caledonia, where temperatures are moderate year-round and humidity is consistently high. Unlike many reptiles, crested geckos do NOT require extreme heat and can actually suffer from overheating. This guide covers how to create appropriate thermal gradients and maintain the high humidity these arboreal geckos require.
Crested geckos need a subtle temperature gradient from warm (top) to cool (bottom). This gradient is naturally created in tall enclosures because heat rises.

content.text: Target Temperature Ranges:

content.content: Temperatures above 82F (28C) cause stress and can lead to illness or death. Avoid heat mats/tape; bottom heat conflicts with natural thermoregulation (heat should come from above if needed).

For complete guidance on heating equipment options and temperature monitoring tools, see our Temperature Monitoring Equipment Guide. Many crested geckos do well at room temperature if your home stays 70-78F. Add gentle overhead heat only if your room drops below 70F.
Crested geckos require high humidity for proper shedding, hydration, and respiratory health. Humidity should fluctuate naturally throughout the day.

content.text: Target Humidity Levels:

rows: Allows enclosure to breathe, prevents mold
Humidity should not drop below this
Daily average balances hydration and drying

content.content: Constant 90%+ humidity without dry-out periods promotes bacterial/fungal growth and respiratory infections. Enclosures MUST dry to 50-60% between mistings to stay healthy.
Maintaining proper humidity requires the right substrate, misting schedule, and enclosure design.

content.text: Humidity Maintenance Methods:
Misting Protocol (Manual):

rows: All walls, plants, and decor (visible droplets)
Heavy misting, substrate should feel damp 1" down
Light mist on plants only, not substrate

content.content: Use treated tap water for misting, NOT distilled or reverse-osmosis water. Tap water contains minerals (calcium, magnesium) that benefit crested geckos.
Ambient room temperature and humidity change with seasons, requiring adjustments to heating and misting.

content.text: Seasonal Climate Management:

rows: Reduce heat lamp wattage or remove entirely if room >78F; reduce misting to 1x daily
Increase heat lamp wattage; add CHE for nighttime; increase misting to 3x daily
Monitor daily, adjust dimmer as needed; standard 2x misting usually sufficient
Increase ventilation, reduce misting frequency, ensure substrate dries between sessions

content.text: Common Problems and Solutions:

rows: Gecko always on floor, gaping mouth, lethargy
Lower wattage, use dimmer, increase ventilation, relocate away from windows
Gecko inactive, not eating, dark coloration
Increase wattage to 50-60w, add CHE for nighttime, check room temperature
Stuck shed, sunken eyes, dry substrate
Increase misting to 3x daily, add live plants, increase substrate depth to 4"
Reduce misting to 1x daily, improve ventilation, decrease substrate moisture
Gecko seems uncomfortable, stays in one spot
Ensure heat lamp is on top only, verify cool zone is 10-15F cooler than basking
Gecko very pale at night, not active at dusk
Add low-wattage CHE on timer (night only), insulate enclosure sides

content.content: Power outages, equipment failures, or extreme weather require emergency intervention to protect your gecko.

content.text: Emergency Interventions:

rows: Hand warmers wrapped in towel near (not in) enclosure, blanket over 3 sides
24-48 hours (crested geckos tolerate cold better than heat)
Move enclosure to coolest room, frozen water bottles outside enclosure, increase air flow
12-24 hours (heat is more dangerous than cold)
Temporary space heater in room (not enclosure), emergency bulb replacement
Remove all heat sources, relocate to air-conditioned room, ice packs outside enclosure
Manual misting 4x daily, damp towel over portion of screen top

content.content: If room temperature exceeds 85F for more than 2-3 hours, move your crested gecko to the coolest room in your house or a basement. Prolonged exposure to temperatures above 88F can be fatal.

content.text: Essential Climate Control Equipment:

content.content: Invest in quality thermometers and hygrometers, cheap analog stick-on gauges are inaccurate by 5-10F and give false confidence. Etekcity 774 infrared gun ($15-20) and any digital probe thermometer ($10-15) are reliable budget options.
